Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI develops arguments for convergent evolution in gene networks based on simulation and bifurcation theory (or the geometric theory of differential equations). This requires defining a measure of fitness that the network optimizes and showing that mutation rates (which are unknown) to not bias the result. Darwin understood that complex organs such as the eye could evolve by continual small changes if all the intermediate steps increased the fitness. The same question will be posed for networks and answered computationally: what networks can be learned by gradient ascent (ie hill climbing). When evolution proceeds by hill climbing, the same local maxima are found irrespective of mutation rates. Generic fitness measures for embryonic patterning and the input-output response of signaling systems are suggested that may capture the phyla-wide properties of developmental networks. In situations where the network produces a static pattern, bifurcation theory enumerates the types of patterns that occur as parameters change continuously. Near the bifurcation point there are simple polynomial equations that collapse many physical variables into a few, and thus provide a description of the system with as few parameters as mathematics allows. Geometric models with fixed points, saddle points and sources may be an effective way to quantitatively model biological networks, and possibly evolution itself. A complementary experimental program will time cell divisions and other markers during embryonic development in the worm C.elegans to see if their fluctuations conform to geometric models. To see whether the structure of developmental signaling pathways can be understood from their input-output response, TGF-beta pathway in Xenopus will be probed with time and space dependent stimuli and time-lapsed imaged in sheets of embryonic cells. Students and postdocs will be engaged in research projects related to this proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biology has one all encompassing theory, Darwinian evolution, but in contrast to those in the physical sciences it is qualified as 'historical' rather than predictive. This grant sought to make biological evolution as applied to genetic networks predictive. The mathematical idea is that gene networks that can be changed incrementally to continuously improve some system level functionality will be preferred, and perhaps observed in nature. One application of these ideas was to temperature compensation in circadian oscillators. All animals and plants have an internal clock that tracks the day-night cycle. This clock runs with the same period irrespective of temperature, which is necessary for life forms that do not regulate their body temperatures (eg insects) but is biochemically non-trivial to achieve since reaction rates typically change by 2x with a 10C temperature change. Using our algorithm for computational evolution, we produced a class of gene networks with the temperature compensation property, and then went on to show that the circadian clock in the fruit fly had exactly the properties we predicted. A second application of the technique predicts how arthropods (eg segmented animals) evolved from species that made their posterior segments sequentially, to those that pattern them all at the same time. 

In other situations we know a great deal from genetics about the components of a gene network, that controls some aspect of development, but the knowledge is qualitative (eg mutate some gene and the correct pattern is made X% of the time, and an aberrant one in the remainder of cases). In this case, we developed parsimonious models that are motivated by the geometric theory of differential equations (eg relating the time rate of change to the underlying genes). The utility of these models is that they collapse a huge number of unknown paramters into a managable few, consistent with the general properties of devlopment. There are many problems in biology, such as cancer, where a plethora of genes impact the final outcome, yet for which we still have very sparse data in comparison with the complexity of the real situation. Geometric models are a method of choice to make true predictions from sparse data.
